subject: Cybersecurity
title: RSA: The Algorithm That Runs the Internet
description: A 1-minute de-risking session on RSA: The Algorithm That Runs the Internet.

hook.text: Three MIT professors invented a way to encrypt with one key and decrypt with another. It changed everything.

buildup.text: RSA uses pairs of keys: a public key anyone can use to encrypt, and a private key only the owner can decrypt with.

discovery.text: Its security relies on the difficulty of factoring large prime numbers â€” easy to multiply, nearly impossible to reverse.

twist.text: GCHQ's Clifford Cocks actually invented the same concept in 1973 â€” but it was classified until 1997.

climax.text: RSA enabled digital commerce, HTTPS, and secure email. The entire internet economy depends on it.

punchline.text: Your credit card is safe because prime numbers are hard to factor.

quiz.question: What mathematical problem does RSA's security rely on?
options: The difficulty of factoring large prime numbers
